awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Virtual Physical Therapy Using Mobile Devices and Artificial Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project includes providing access to physical therapy to large sections of society who cannot access clinic-based physical therapy for economic, geographic or health mobility reasons. The new system will focus initially on patients with stroke and various orthopedic conditions. By providing accurate, automated movement guidance to patients at home, the project aims to provide more timely, personalized physical therapy.  Caregivers will have the ability to track the compliance and effectiveness of physical therapy.  More effective patient engagement may lead to better health outcomes. Physical therapy clinics will be enabled to expand and scale up their businesses to reach a much larger customer base with innovative hybrid business models combining in-person, remote, and virtual therapy sessions. This type of system can enable other healthcare training applications and more meaningful video visits. The broader impacts of this project also include offering training in market-driven research, technology development, commercialization and entrepreneurship to the project team as well as broadening participation of women and underrepresented minority entrepreneurs in the commercialization effort. Thus, successful development and deployment of the virtual physical therapy system will have broad societal, commercial and educational benefits.
 
The project creates a virtual physical therapy system by combining innovations in machine vision, artificial intelligence and mobile video technologies to ensure deep physical therapy expertise can be made available anywhere, with high accuracy, and in a personalized and timely fashion. For many medical conditions, ensuring proper exercise techniques throughout rehabilitation is very important, and constitutes a significant portion of a treatment session.  Exercise quality performed by patients at home can vary.  Some exercises can be harmful if performed incorrectly, causing painful setbacks. The team seeks to develop an advanced prototype of a virtual physical therapy system which can be used by patients anywhere with just a mobile device - either for live sessions with a remote therapist or for sessions with a machine-learning-based avatar which emulates a therapist with important real-time guidance. Successful implementation of the integrated solution will involve motion tracking and force estimation algorithms using mobile device cameras and machine learning algorithms for patient performance evaluation, with understanding of contextual and human factors that may guide judgment of physical therapists.  The avatar and guidance rendering algorithms will minimize both human reaction and network latency in ways that can be most effective for patient training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
PocketPT: Virtual Physical Therapy Using Mobile Devices and Artificial Intelligence

Recent advances in 3D Human Pose Estimation (HPE) technology, combined with our deep learning algorithms, marks a significant advancement in the development of AI-assisted coaching for physical therapy exercises at-home. Our developed technology, PocketPT, utilizes the processing power of modern mobile phones to facilitate real-time computations, allowing physical therapy patients to engage with real-time feedback for performing at-home exercises. Adherence to at-home exercises is known to be a leading indicator for successful recovery, but also notoriously the most difficult to track and encourage; PocketPT shows the potential to provide our society with a tool that allows for a healthier population. 

Intellectual Merit

This project studied the use of 3D HPE, running on common smartphone devices, for assessing the correctness of physical exercises in real-time. Whereas traditional techniques require specialized hardware, PocketPT can capture and analyze the three-dimensional movements of the human body using mobile devices with remarkable speed and accuracy. This serves to guide individuals through physical therapy exercises in a precise and personalized manner.

Our AI-driven approach is particularly beneficial for at-home physical therapy sessions, where professional supervision is limited. The system not only provides real-time feedback on the correctness of exercises but also tailors the suggestive guidance to the individual's specific needs and progress. This level of customization was previously unachievable in standard physical therapy practices.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this project are far-reaching and multifaceted. Firstly, the accessibility of this technology promises to make physical therapy more affordable. By reducing the need for frequent in-person sessions with therapists, patients can save time and costs while still receiving personalized care.

Secondly, the project addresses the challenge of accessibility for individuals living in remote or underserved areas. With PocketPT, quality physical therapy becomes available to anyone with a smartphone, eliminating geographical barriers to healthcare.

Thirdly, the widespread adoption of this AI-assisted physical therapy has the potential to significantly improve the overall health of the population. By providing an effective, convenient, and personalized way to undergo rehabilitation, more individuals are likely to adhere to their therapy regimens, leading to better health outcomes.

Moreover, the technology offers substantial support to the physical therapy profession. Overworked physical therapists can utilize this AI system as an assistant, allowing them to manage their workload more efficiently and focus on cases that require more specialized attention.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the integration of 3D HPE and deep learning for at-home physical therapy exercises represents a major advancement in medical technology. Its intellectual merits, combined with its broad and positive societal impacts, underscore the potential of this project to revolutionize the field of physical rehabilitation. As the technology continues to evolve and become more refined, it promises to enhance the quality of life for individuals requiring physical therapy, while also supporting the professionals in this vital healthcare sector.

 


Last Modified: 01/18/2024
Modified by: Sujit Dey
